title: 115_s686
content: The Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2017 aims to improve regulatory analysis and review to enhance agency decisions and reduce unwarranted costs. It emphasizes the importance of disclosing key information to make the Federal Government more accountable to the public. The Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2017 focuses on enhancing regulatory analysis and review to reduce unnecessary costs and improve agency decision-making. Section 202 specifically addresses regulatory impact analyses for certain rules. The Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2017 enhances regulatory analysis by requiring agencies to prepare regulatory impact analyses for rules with significant economic effects. The term 'cost' includes compliance costs and indirect costs. Agencies must conduct initial and final regulatory impact analyses for rules with a significant economic impact. The Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2017 mandates agencies to conduct initial and final regulatory impact analyses for rules with significant economic effects. The analyses must include an assessment of anticipated benefits and costs, quantified where possible, and consider a range of regulatory alternatives, including those that require no federal action and utilize incentives for desired behavior. The Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2017 requires agencies to conduct regulatory impact analyses for rules with significant economic effects. The analyses must include an assessment of benefits and costs, consider regulatory alternatives, and provide information for public choices. The rule must comply with section 205 requirements and assess the costs to State, local, and tribal governments. The Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2017 mandates agencies to conduct regulatory impact analyses for rules with significant economic effects. The analyses must assess benefits and costs, consider regulatory alternatives, and provide information for public choices. The rule must comply with section 205 requirements and evaluate the impact on job creation or loss, as well as consult with elected representatives of affected State, local, or tribal governments. The rule must include a summary of the information in the analysis. Subsection (e) requires any analysis under subsection (b) to meet the requirements of subsections (b) and (c). SEC. 4 amends the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act to require agencies to consider and select the least burdensome regulatory alternative when proposing or finalizing a rule. SEC. 5 extends this requirement to independent regulatory agencies. SEC. 5 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include independent regulatory agencies. It also adds an exemption for monetary policy rules proposed by the Federal Reserve. SEC. 6 amends the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act to include judicial review provisions. SEC. 401 grants judicial review for final agency actions on rules subject to section 202. Courts with jurisdiction under title 5 can review compliance with specific sections. Relief ordered must align with title 5. SEC. 7 states the Act takes effect 90 days after enactment.
